qas.question: What nearby settlement built ships for the Royal Navy?
In what year did Plymouth become a city?
What is the term used to describe the attacks on Plymouth during the Second World War?
In what year was Plymstock incorporated?
Along with Plymouth and Devonport, what location was merged into a county borough in 1914?

context: Throughout the Industrial Revolution, Plymouth grew as a commercial shipping port, handling imports and passengers from the Americas, and exporting local minerals (tin, copper, lime, china clay and arsenic) while the neighbouring town of <a0_0>Devonport<a0_0/> became a strategic Royal Naval shipbuilding and dockyard town. In 1914 three neighbouring independent towns, viz., the county borough of Plymouth, the county borough of Devonport, and the urban district of <a4_0>East Stonehouse<a4_0/> were merged to form a single County Borough. The combined town took the name of Plymouth which, in <a1_0>1928<a1_0/>, achieved city status. The city's naval importance later led to its targeting and partial destruction during World War II, an act known as the <a2_0>Plymouth Blitz<a2_0/>. After the war the city centre was completely rebuilt and subsequent expansion led to the incorporation of Plympton and Plymstock along with other outlying suburbs in <a3_0>1967<a3_0/>.
